It is good to ſee by another mans harm what things are to be avoided.
To receive a courteſie is to ſell ones liberty.
An hour is not ſo good to any body that is not ill to ſome.
It's a double death to any body to dye at anothers pleaſure.
He receives more courteſie that knows how to requite them.
You ſin twice when you humour him that ſins.
A mild diſpoſition provoked is far more grievouſly angry.
A mans death is good which puts an end to the evils of his life.
He bath received a courteſie by doing one, that did it to a deſerving perſon.
Venus is ſweetned by fair means, not by a great hand.
An honeſt man never humoureth one that doth amiſs.
He that ſaith he hath done a courteſie begs one.
A loving dispoſition is the greateſt friendſhip.
Often to beſtow a courteſie is to teach one to requite it.
To imitate the words of goodneſs is the greater malice.
A mans good opinion is ſafer than money.
A good thing, though it be ſupprest, is not extinguiſhed.
He conquers twice that conquers himſelf in victory.
A kind man ſtudies an opportunity to give.
He is twice kill'd that dyeth by his own weapons.
He ſleeps well that doth not feel how ill he ſleeps.
An honeſt man in want is the blame of good men.
A good name keeps its own luſtre in the dark.
Good intentions though they come ſhort, yet they are not loſt.
He loſeth his money well, when a guilty perſon bribes the Judge.
He wrongeth good men whoſoever ſpares them that are bad.
Severity in a good man is the next to juſtice.
Anger quickly dieth with a good man.
It is a good ſhame which diſcovereth the danger.
Mercy gets good ſuccour.
Common uſe of good things is very bad.
When you beſtow a courteſie upon worthy perſons you engage all.
Chiding is cruel in adverſity.
We omit opportunity to beware.
To one that you are always giving, when you deny him, you bid him take it by force.
An intemperate patient makes a cruel Doctor.
They hate his life whoſe death friends wait for.
No man is quickly friends with an enemy.
A danger that is ſlighted comes the ſooner.
A wife that is chaſte towards her husband commands him by obeying him.
A proud man's glory doth quickly become his diſgrace.
You may better overcome one by advice than by anger.
Patience is a remedy for every grief.
When vices afford profit, he ſins that doth well.
It is better to be ſcorned than to commit folly.
A merry talking companion upon the high way is as good as a coach.
The proſperity of the wicked quickly comes to nought.
He leaveth an imputation upon life who deſires death.
He that is ſuffered to more than is fitting will do more than is lawful.
To chide when there is need of advice is to condemn.
The day following is a ſcholar to the day before it.
You muſt be long in preparing War that you may overcome the ſooner.
You have called him all the ill names that can be when you have called a man ingrateful.
Speak not evil of thine enemy, if thou thinkeſt it.
To conſider what may be good is the ſafest delay.
Grief grows leſs when it hath not wherewith to increaſe it:
It is a lie, that a woman doth learn not to weep.
Concord is made more intire by diſcord.
We muſt conſider long of what we muſt once reſolve upon.
We muſt not readily hearken to accuſations.
Whilſt life is pleaſing, then is the best dying.
Gain with an ill name is to be called loſs.
The valour of the Souldiers conſists in the diſcretion of the Commander.
What a day beſtows be afraid to loſe it, it comes quickly to take it away.
A thing foregone that is not known, is not loſt.
Pain inforceth even innocent perſons to lie.
Faith is honeſtly kept even in a bad matter.
Even ſpeed is a delay when there is a deſire.
A wiſe man mendeth his own faults by another mans.
Men in miſery take too much, and too little thought.
Fortune is thought to be a Goddeſs by peoples gain.
To avoid a luſt is to conquer a Kingdom.
When a baniſhed man hath no dwelling, he is like a dead man without a grave.
Even they that do an injury deteſt it.
It is fit to take a weapon from, and not to give one to, an angry man.
To deny himſelf to his own Country is to endure baniſhment.
Even one hair hath its ſhadow.
Alas, what a miſerable thing is it to become old by fearing!
He is fair even to his enemy that hath faith in his counſel.
A falt hurts them that are in a higher place a great deal the more.
He that hath loſt his credit, with what can he maintain himſelf after?
120. What fortune flattereth ſhe comes to catch.
You may eaſilier get an eſtate, than keep it.
A handſome ſace is a ſtlent commendation.
He is entreated in vain that cannot ſhew pity.
It is couzenage to receive what you are not able to reſtore.
Fortune makes him a fool whom ſhe makes too much on.
He confeſſeth the fault that avoids the judgment.
Proſpering wickedneſs is the undoing of good men.
Thou muſt bear, and not blame what thou canſt not avoid.
Future things ſo ſight, as they ſuffer themſelves to be overcome.
Wronged patience doth oft become fury.
Feigned things will quickly come to their own nature.
He that loſeth his credit can loſe nothing elſe.
Gentleneſs of diſpoſition carries one on to ſolly.
Credit, as the ſoul, never returns thither whence it went.
No body ever loſt his credit, but he that had it not.
Fortune is not content to hurt one once.
Wrath is a thunder-bolt, where it dwells with power.
When thou art grown old, thou ſhalt ſtrive to no purpoſe to be young again.
A falſe railing-tearm is a malicious lye.
To rule a womans nature is the deſpair of all men.
Endure things eaſie, that you may bear them that are difficult.
Fortune doth none more good than counſel doth.
Fortune is of glaſs which when it ſhines it is broken.
Thou muſt bear what doth thee hurt, that thou may'ſt thorowly bear what doth thee good.
Fortune that no man ſeeth, maketh one acceptable.
Thriftineſs is the miſery of a good report.
That prejudice is heavy which hath not a judgment.
The wrath of an honeſt man is very heavy.
That mind is grievouſly puniſhed which repents after the deed.
A grieved mind hath not a double ſentence.
Every evil is grievous that lyeth under a mask.
Whatever befalls that never was tryed before, doth hurt worſe.
The enemy is moſt grievous that lurketh in ones breaſt.
The rule of cuſtom is moſt troubleſome.
155. A great crime doth hurt, even when it is but lightly ſpoken of.
Alas, how hard a thing is the keeping of ones renown!
A man is not in his own body, when he is angry.
Alas, how much is he to be feared, that thinks it ſafe to dye!
A man that is pitiful to a man in miſery, remembers himſelf.
It is an honeſt diſgrace to dye for a good cauſe.
He that doth good in proſperity, hath ſuccour in adverſity.
Alas, what a miſerable thing it is to be hurt of him of whom you cannot complain!
Poverty bids a man try many things.
Alas, how miſerable is that pain which may not ſpeak in the torment.
Alas, what things to be repented of do men run into, by living long!
A fair ſpeech hath its poyſon.
A man dyeth ſo often as he loſeth his children.
A man alwayes carries one thing towards himſelf, and thinks another thing towards another.
An honeſt report is a good patrimony.
A man feels it not if he finds profit by his ſmart.
He ſerves honestly, that yields to the times.
A man hath his life lent him, not given him.
It is better to know ones heir, than to ſeek one.
An heirs weeping is laughing under a Vizzard.
Often marriages have room for a curſe.
An inferior ſtartles at what a ſuperiour doth amiſs.
To revenge an enemy is to receive another life.
Have a care that no body hate thee through thine own demerit:
When you hold one againſt his will, you hast him to be gone.
You wrong breeding when you intreat an unworthy man.
A covetous man is good to no body, and he is worſt to himſelf.
He doth a courteſie twice to a poor man, that doth it quickly.
Deſire of more amongſt riches, is a rich want.
He inviteth a fault, that paſſeth by an offence!
There is nothing pleaſant but that which variety refreſheth.
A generous ſpirit minds not an affront.
One offends without puniſhment against him that offends but ſeldom.
One ingrateful perſon wrongs all poor men.
There is no reproach in a poor mans life.
A poor man wants a few things, a covetous man all things.
So uſe your friend, as to think he may become your enemy.
A stout man, or a proſperous man can endure envy.
Anger is always a lye in love matters.
Envy is angry cloſely, and upon a ſmall occaſion.
Shun an angry man for a while, an enemy for a long time.
Forgetfulneſs is the remedy of wrongs.
He that overcomes anger, conquers his greateſt enemy.
No body uſeth to hope for good in afflictions, but the innocent.
Haſtineſs is to blame in taking revenge.
It is a wiſe mans part to fear his enemy though never ſo mean.
Laughing at men in miſery is even an injury.
The judge is condemned, when the guilty man is acquitted.
It is a kind part to pardon, when he is ſorry that is pardoned.
Boldnefs can do very much in doubtful things.
A guilty perſon condemns himſelf on the ſame day he offends.
So truſt your friend, that there be no room for an enemy.
An angry man thinks even advice to be a hainous crime.
He badly blames Neptune that again ſuffers ſhipwrack.
Honour with an unworthy perſon is inſtead of a diſgrace.
When a new commendation is offered, even the old is admitted.
The ſmart of his enemy is the remedy of him that is hurt.
Fortune is unconſtant; ſhe quickly asks again what ſhe hath given.
It is an univerſal law which bids, Be born and dye.
Gain cannot be made without anothers loſs.
Wantonneſs and praiſe do never agree.
The guilty perſon fears the Law, and the innocent fortune.
Exceſs wants many things, but covetouſneſs all things.
Ingrateful perſons, eſpecially teach men to be hard.
He threatneth many that doth a wrong to one.
All delay is diſtaſtful, yet it makes men wiſe.
It is a bad cauſe which requires pity.
It is a happy mans lot to dye, before he calleth death.
It is a miſerable thing to be forced to keep that ſilent which you deſire to ſpeak.
That fortune is moſt miſerable that wants an enemy.
He is to be called bad that is good for his own ends.
A bad man is then the worſt, when he feigns himſelf good.
When fear cometh, ſleep hath but ſeldom place.
Thou muſt needs dye, but not ſo oft as thou wouldst.
It is badly done, whatever is done with relying upon future.
He that ſends a preſent to a dead man, takes from himſelf, and gives him nothing.
A maſter that is afraid of his ſervants is leſs than a ſervant.
A true heir is rather born than written.
Women out-ſtrip men in bad counſel.
It is bad pleaſure to uſe our ſelves to other folks things.
That is kept with a great deal of danger which pleaſeth many.
The cure is bad, when any thing of nature is lost.
Bad natures never need teaching.
To live without danger is not to know miſery.
They live ill who think they ſhall always live.
By conſtruing a foul word you will make it worſe.
The patient deals badly with himſelf that makes the Phyſician his heir.
He is leſs deceived that is ſooner denyed.
Goodneſs changeth it ſelf, which an injury provokes.
When a woman muſeth all alone, ſhe muſeth ſome miſchief.
He that will do a ſhrewd turn will every where find an occaſion.
A naughty natur'd man feeds on his own nature.
He ought to fear many, whom many fear.
The greatest command is lost by badly commanding.
A woman that is married to many men doth not pleaſe many.
It is bad counſel which cannot be altered.
It is the best for an unfortunate perſon to do nothing.
The eyes would not offend at all, if the mind could rule the eyes.
Eſteem nothing thine own that may be altered.
A man doth lightly dye with the fall (of a houſe) that is, afraid of the fall (of it.)
Thou know'ſt not what to wiſh, or what to avoid; the day ſo dallieth.
Danger is never overcome without danger.
There is no fortune ſo good, of which thou may'ſt not complain.
We men dye better no where, than where we had a mind to live.
A covetous man never wants an excuſe to deny (one.)
The truth is loſt with too much wrangling.
He is every day condemned that alwayes feareth.
The latter day is always the worſe.
It is a ridiculous thing to deſtroy innocency, in deteſtation of one that is nocent.
It is a piece of good turn, if thou well deny what is deſired.
It is a fond thing to fear what cannot be avoided.
A fearful man calls himſelf a wary man, and a baſe fellow calls himſelf a good Husband.

By putting up an old injury, thou
maiſt avoid
inviteſt a new one.
A covetous man as well wanteth what he hath, as what he hath not.
O life, that art long to one in miſery, and ſhort to one in proſperity.
ALienum eſt omne quicquid oprando evenit.
Ab alio expectes alteri quod feceris.
Animus vereri qui ſcit, ſcit tutò aggredi.
Auxilia humilia firma conſenſus facit.
Amor animi arbitrio ſumitur, non ponitur.
Aut amat, aut odit mulier, nihil eſt tertium.
Ad triſtem partem ſtrenua ſuſpicio.
Ames parentem, ſi aequus eſt; ſi aliter, feras.
Aſpicere oportet quod poſſis deperdere.
Amici vitia ſi feras, facis tua.
Aliena homini ingenuo acerba eſt ſervitus.
Abſentem laedit cum ebrio qui litigat.
Amans iratus multa mentitur ſibi.
Avarus ipſe miſeriae cauſa eſt ſuae.
Amans quid cupiat, ſcit, quid ſapiat, non videt,
Amans, quod ſuſpicatur vigilans ſomniat.
Ad calamitatem quilibet rumor valet.
Amor extorqueri non poteſt, elabi poteſt.
Ab amante lachrymis redimas iracundiam.
Apertè mala cùm eſt mulier, tum demum eſt bona.
Avarum facilè capias, ubi non ſis idem.
Amare & ſapere vix deo couceditur.
Avarus, niſi cùm moritur, nihil rectè facit.
Aſtute, dum celatur, ſe aetas indicat.
Avarus damno potius quam ſapiens dolet.
Avaro quid mali optes, niſi ut vivat diu?

l.hi: Animo dolenti nihil oportet credere.
Alienum nobis, noſtrum plus aliis, placet.

lg.l: Amare juveni fructus eſt, crimen ſeni.
Anus cum ludit, morti delicias facit.
Amoris vulnus, idem, qui ſanat, facit.
Ad paenirendum properat citò qui judicat.
Amicos res optimae parant, adverſae probant.
Aleator, quantò in arte eſt melior, tantò eſt nequior.
Arcum intenſio frangit, animum remiſſio.
Bis eſt gratum, quod opus eſt, ultrò ſi offeras.
Beneficium dare qui neſcit injuſtè petit.
Bonum eſt fugienda aſpicere alieno in malo.
Beneficium accipere, libertatem vendere eſt.
Bona nemini hora eſt ut non alicui ſit mala.
Bis cuique mori eſt, alterius arbitrio mori.
Beneficia plura recipit qui ſcit reddere.
Bis peccas cùm peccanti obſequium accommodas.
Bonus animus laeſus gravius mu •… ò iraſcitur.
Bona mors eſt hominis vitae quae extinguit mala.
Beneficium dando accipit, qui digno dedit.
Blanditio non imperio, fit dulcis Venus.
Bonus animus nunquam erranti obſequium accommodat.
Beneficium ſe dediſſe qui dicit, petit.
Benevolus animus maxima eſt cognatio.
Beneficium ſaepe dare, docere eſt reddere.
Bonitatis verba imitari, major malitia eſt.
Bona opinio hominis tutior pecunia eſt.
Bonum tametſi ſupprimitur non extinguitur.
Bis vincit qui ſe vincit in victoria.

l.hi: Benignus etiam dandi cauſam cogitat.
Bis interimitur qui ſuis armis perit.
Bene dormit qui non ſentit, quàm malè dormiat.
Bonorum crimen eſt honeſtus miſer.
Bona fama in tenebris proprium ſplendorem obtinet:
Bene cogitata, ſi excidunt, non occidunt.

lg.l: Bene perdit nummos judici cum dat nocens.
Bonis nocet quiſquis pepercerit malis.
Bonum apud virum juſtitiae proxima eſt ſeveritas.
Bonum apud virum citò moritur iracundia.
Bona turpitudo eſt quae periculum indicat.
Bona comparat praeſidia miſericordia.
Bonarum rerum conſuetudo peſſima eſt.
Beneficium dignis ubi das, omnes obligas.
Crudelis in re adverſa eſt objurgatio.
Cavendi nulla eſt dimittenda occaſio.
Cui ſemper dederis, ubi neges, rapere imperas.
Crudelem medicum intemperansaeger facit.
Cujus mortem amici expectant, vitam oderunt.
Cum inimico nemo in gratiam citò redit.
Citiùs venit periculum quod contemnitur.
Caſta ad virum matrona parendo imperat.
Cito ignominia fit ſuperbi gloria.
Conſilio meliùs vincas, quàm iracundia.
Cuivis dolori remedium eſt patientia.
Cùm vitia proſunt peccat qui rectè facit.
Contemni eſt levius, quam ſtultitiâ percuti.
Comes ſacundus in via pro vehiculo eſt.
Cirò improborum laetitia in perniciem cadit.
Crimemrelinquit vitae qui mortem appetit.
Cui plus licet quàm par eſt, plus vult quàm licet.

l.hi: Damnare eſt objurgare, cum conſilio eſt opus.
Diſcipulus eſt prioris poſterior dies.
Diu operandum eſt bellum, ut vincas celerius.

lg.l: Dixeris maledicta cuncta, cum ingratum hominem dixeris.
De inimico ne loquare malum ſi cogites.
Deliberare utilia mora tutiſſima eſt.
Dolor decreſcit, ubi quo creſcat non habet.
Dediſcere flere ſoeminam, eſt mendacium.
Diſcordia ſit charior concordia.
Deliberandum eſt diu, quod ſtatuendum eſt ſemel.
Difficilem opportet aurem habere ad crimina.
Dum vita grata eſt, mortis conditio optima eſt.
Damnum appellandum eſt cum mala fama lucrum.
Ducis in conſilio poſita eſt virtus militum.
Dies quod donat, timeas amittere; citò raptum venit.
Dimiſſum, quod neſcitur, non amittitur.
Etiam innocentes cogit mentiri dolor.
Etiam peccato rectè praeſtatur fides.
Etiam celeritas in deſiderio mora eſt.
Ex vitio alterius ſapiens emendat ſuum.
Et deeſt & ſupereſt, miſeris cogitatio.
Etiam obliviſci quod ſcis interdum expedit.
Ex hominum quaeſtu facta fortuna eſt dea.
Effugere cupiditatem, regnum eſt vincere.
Exuli ubi nuſquam domus eſt, ſine ſepulchro eſt tanquam mortuus.
Etiam qui faciunt, odio habent injuriam.
Eripere telum, non dare irato decet.
Exilium eſt pati, ſe denegare patriae.
Etiam capillus unus habet umbram ſuam.
Eheu quam miſerum eſt, fieri metuendo ſenem!
Etiam hoſti eſt aequus, qui non habet in confilio fidem.
Excelſis multo facilius caſus nocet.
Fidem qui perdit, quò ſe ſervet in reliquam?
120. Fortuna cùm blanditur, captarum venit.
Fortunam citiùs reperias quàm retineas.
Formoſa facies muta commendatio eſt.
Fruſtrà rogatur qui miſereri non poteſt.
Fraus eſt accipere quod non poſſis reddere.
Fortuna nimium quem fovet, ſtultum facit.
Fatetur facinus, qui judicium fugit.
Foelix improbitas optimorum eſt calamitas.
Feras▪ non culpes, qnod vitare non potes.
Futura pugnant, ut ſe ſuperari ſinant.
Furor fit laeſa ſaepiùs patientia.
Ficta citò ad naturam redierint ſuam.
Fidem qui perdit nil poteſt ultrà perdere.
Facilitas animi ad partem ſtultitiae rapit.
Fides, ut anima, unde abiit nunquam eò redit.
Fidem nemo unquam perdit, niſi qui non habet.
Fortuna obeſſe nulli contenta eſt ſemel.
Fulmen eſt, ubi cum poteſtate habitat iracundia.
Fruſtra, cùm ad ſenectam ventum eſt, repetes adoleſcentiam.
Falſum maledictum malevolum mendacium eſt.
Foeminae naturam regere, deſperare eſt omnium.
Fer difficilia, ut facilia feras.
Fortuna nulli plus quam conſilium valet▪
Fortuna vitrea eſt, quae, cum ſplendet, frangitur.
Feras quod laedit, ut quod prodeſt perferas.
Facit gratum fortuna quam nemo videt.
Frugalītas miſeria eſt rumoris boni.
Grave praejudicium eſt, quod judicium non habet.
Graviſſima eſt probi hominis iracundia.
Gravis animi poena eſt, quem poſt factum poenitet.
Gravis animus dubiam non habet ſententiam.
Grave eſt malum omne quod ſub aſpectu lacet.
Graviùs nocet quodcunque inexpertum accidit.
Gravior inimicus, qui latet ſub pectore.
Graviſſimum eſt imperium conſuetudinis.
155. Gra 〈…〉 n, etiam cum dictum eſt leviter, nocet.
Heu quam difficile eſt gloriae cuſtodia!
Homo extra corpus eſt ſuum cùm iraſcitur.
Heu quam eſt timendus, quicunque mori tutum putat!
Homo qui in homine calamitoſo eſt miſericors, meminit ſui.
Honeſta eſt turpitudo pro bonâ cauſâ mori.
Habet in adverſis auxilia qui in ſecundis commodat.
Heu, quàm miſerum eſt laedi ab illo de quo non poſſis queri!
Hominem experiri multa paupertas jubet.
Heu dolor quam miſer eſt, qui in tormento vocem non habet!
Heu, quàm poenitenda incurrunt homines, vivendo diu!
Habet ſuum venenum blanda oratio.
Homo coties moritur, quoties amittit ſuos.
Homo ſemper in ſeſe aliud fert, in alterum aliud cogitat.
Honeſtus rumor alterum eſt patrimonium.
Homo neſcit, ſi dolore fortunam invenit.
Honeſtè ſervit qui ſuccumbit tempori.
Homo vitâ commodatus, non donatus eſt.
Haeredem ſcire utilius eſt, quàm quaerere.
Haeredis fletus ſub perſonâ riſus eſt.
Habent locum maledicti crebrae nuptiae.
Inferior horret quicquid peccat ſuperior.
Inimicum ulciſci vitam accipere eſt alteram.
Id agas, ne quis tuo te merito oderit.
Invi • um cum retineas, exire incitas.
Ingenuitatem laedis, cum indignum rogas.
In nullum avarus bonus eſt, in ſe peſſimus.
Inopi beneficium bis dat, qui dat celeriter.
Inſtructa inopia eſt in diviriis cupiditas.
Invita • culpam qui peccatum praeterit.
Jucundum nihil eſt niſi quod reficit varietas.
Ingenuitas non recipit contumeliam.
Impunè peccat in eum qui peccat rarior.
Ingratus unus miſeris omnibus nocet.
In miſeri vita nulla contumelia eſt.
Inopiae parva deſunt, avaritiae omnia.
Ita amicum habeas, poſſe ut fieri inimicum putes.
Invidiam ferre aut fortis, aut foelix poteſt.
In amore mendax ſemper iracundia.
Invidia tacitè, ſed minutè, iraſcitur.
Iratum breviter vites, inimicum diu.
Injuriarum remedium eſt oblivio.
Iram qui vincit, hoſtem ſuperat maximum.
In malis-ſperare bonum, niſi innocens, nemo ſolet.
In vindicando criminoſa eſt celeritas.
Inimicum, quamvis humilem, docti eſt metuere.
In calamitoſos riſus etiam injuria eſt.
Judex damnatur, cum nocens abſolvitur.
Ignoſcere humanum, ubi pudet cui ignoſcitur.
In rebus dubiis plurimi eſt audacia.
Illo nocens ſe damnat quo peccat die.
Ita crede amico, ne ſit inimico locus.
Iratus etiam facinus conſilium putat.
Improbè Neptunum accuſat qui iterum naufragium facit.
Loco ignominiae eſt apud indignum dignitas.
Laus ubi nova oritur, etiam vetus admitritur.
Laeſo doloris remedium inimici dolor.
Levis eſt fortuna, citò repoſcit quae dedit.
Lex univerſa eſt, quae jubet naſci & mori.
Lucrum ſine damno alterius fieri non poreſt.
Laſcivia & laus nunquam habent concordiam.
Legem nocens veretur, fortunam innocens,
Luxuriae deſunt multa, avaritiae omnia.
Malignos fieri maximè ingrati docent.
Multis minatur qui uni facit injuriam.
220. Mora omnis odio eſt, ſed facit ſapientiam.
Mala cauſa eſt, quae requirit miſericordiam.
Mori eſt felicis, antequam mortem invocet.
Miſerum eſt tacere cogi quod cupias loqui.
Miſerrima eſt fortuna quae inimico caret.
Malus eſt vocandus, qui ſuâ cauſâ eſt bonus.
Malus, ubi bonum ſe ſimulat, cunc eſt peſſimus.
Metus cùm venit, rarum habet ſomnus locum.
Mori neceſſe eſt, ſed non quoties volueris.
Malè geritur quicquid geritur fortunae fide.
Mortuo qui mittit munus, nil dat illi, adimit ſibi.
Minor eſt quàm ſervus dominus qui ſervos timet.
Magis haeres fidus naſcitur quàm ſcribitur.
Malo in conſilio ſoeminae vincunt viros.
Mala eſt voluptas, alienis aſſueſcere.
Magno cum periculo cuſtoditur, quod multis placet.
Mala eſt medicina, ubi aliquid naturae perit.
Malae naturae nunquam doctrinâ indigent.
Miſeriam neſcire, eſt, ſine periculo vivere.
Malè vivunt qui ſemper victuros ſe putant.
Maledictum interpretando, facies acrius.
Malè ſecum agit aegrotus, medicum qui heredem facit.
Minus decipitur cui negatur celeriter.
Mutat ſe bonitas, quam irritat injuria.
Mulier, cum ſola cogitat malè cogitat.
Malefacere qui vult, nuſquam non cauſam invenit.
Malevolus ſemper ſuâ naturâ veſcitur.
Multos timere debet, quem multi timent.
Male imperando ſummum imperium amittitur.
Mulier quae nubit multis, multis non placet.
Malum conſilium eſt quod mutari non poteſt.
Nihil agere, ſemper infelici eſt optimum.
Nihil peccant oculi, ſi animus oculis imperet.
Nihil proprium ducas quod mutari poſſit.
Non citò ruinâ perit vir qui ruinam timet.
Neſcis quid optes, aut quid fugias, ita ludit dies.
Nunquam periculum ſine periculo vincitur.
Nulla tam bona eſt fortuna, de quâ nil poſſis queri.
Nuſquam melius morimur homines quàm ubi libenter vivimus.
Negandi cauſa avaro nunquam deficit.
Nimium altercando veritas amittitur.
Quotidie damnatur qui ſemper timet.
Quotidie eſt deterior poſterior dies.
Ridiculum eſt, odio nocentis, perdere innocentiam.
Pars beneficii eſt, quod petitur, bene ſi neges.
Stultum eſt timere quod vitari non poteſt.
Timidus vocat ſe cautum, parcum ſordidus.

Veterem ferendo injuriam
vites
invitas novam.
Tam deeſt avaro quod habet, quam quod non habet.
O vita, miſero longa, foelici brevis.

div.head: Eraſm. Rot. Epiſt. to Joh. Nervius.
div.p: WHo would ſlight Publius's Stage verſes? which Aulus Gellius calleth very pretty; and Seneca very eloquent ones; and whoſe ſentences (as the ſame man witneſſeth) the greateſt Rhetoricians did not think much to imitate.

div.head: Eraſm. Rot. Epiſt. ad Joh. Nervium.
div.p: PUblii mimos quis contemnat? quos Aulus Gellius lepidiſſimos; Seneca, diſertiſſimos vocat; cujuſque ſententias (ut idem teſtatur) non piguit ſummos etiam Rhetores aemulari.

div.head: Cato conſtrued Grammatically, with one row of Latin, and another of Engliſh.

lg.l: SI Deus eſt animus, ut carmina dicunt nobis.

l.hi: If God be a Spirit, as Poets tell us.

lg.l: Hic praecipuè ſit colendus tibi purâ mente.

l.hi: Let him eſpecially be worſhipped of thee with a pure mind.

lg.l: Semper vigila plus, nec eſto deditus ſomno.

l.hi: Always watch more, and be not given to ſleep.

lg.l: Nam diuturna quies miniſtrat alimenta vitiis.

l.hi: For, long continued reſt affordeth nouriſhment to vices.

lg.l: Puta eſſe primam virtutem compeſcere linguam;

l.hi: Think it to be the prime vertue to rule the Tongue.

lg.l: Ille eſt proximus Deo qui ſcit tacere ratione.

l.hi: He is the neareſt to God that knoweth to hold his tongue with reaſon.

lg.l: Tu ſperne eſſe contrarius tibi repugnando.

l.hi: Do thou ſcorn to be contrary to thy ſelf by being croſs.

lg.l: Ipſe qui diffidet ſecum conveniet nulli.

l.hi: He that falls out with himſelf will agree with no body.

lg.l:
Si inſpicias vitam hominum, deni
que ſi (inſpicias) mores.

l.hi: If thou look into the life of men, laſtly, (if thou look into their) manners.

lg.l: Cum culpent alios, nemo vivit ſine crimine.

l.hi: When they blame others, no man liveth without fault.

lg.l: Relinque (ea) quae tenes nocitura, quamvis ſint chara.

l.hi: Leave (thoſe things) which thou holdeſt that they will do thee hurt, though they be dear.

lg.l: Utilitas debet praeponi opibus, tempore.

l.hi: Benefit ought to be preferr'd before wealth, in ſeaſon.

lg.l: Eſto conſtans & lenis, ſicut res poſtulat.

l.hi: Be grave and remiſs as the matter requireth.

lg.l: Sapiens mutat mores temporibus ſine crimine.

l.hi: A wiſe man alters his manners with the times without fault.

lg.l: Crede nil temerè uxori querenti de ſervis:

l.hi: Believe not raſhly thy wife complaining of thy ſervants:

lg.l: Etenim mulier ſaepe odit quem conjux diligit.

l.hi: For a woman oftentimes hateth whom her husband loveth.

lg.l: Et cum mones aliquem, nec ipſe velit ſe moneri.

l.hi: And when thou adviſeſt one, and he is not willing that himſelf ſhould be adviſea.

lg.l: Si ſit charus tibi, noli deſiſtere coeptis.

l.hi: If he be dear to thee, do not deſiſt fom thy beginning.

lg.l: Noli contende •• verbis contra verboſos.

l.hi: Do not ſtrive in words against men full of words.

lg.l: Sermo datur cunctis, ſapientia animi paucis.

l.hi: Speech is given to all, (but) wiſdom of mind to few.

lg.l: Sic dilige alios, ut ſis charus amicus tibi:

l.hi: So love others that thou may'ſt be a dear friend to thy ſelf:

lg.l: Eſto ſic bonus bonis, nè mala damna ſequantur te.

l.hi: Be ſo good to good men, that evil loſſes may not follow thee.

lg.l: Fuge rumores, ne incipias haberi novus autor.

l.hi: Shun reports, leſt thou begin to be accounted a new author.

lg.l: Nam nocet nulli tacuiſſe, nocet locutum eſſe.

l.hi: For it hurteth none to have held his peace, it hurteth to have ſpoken.

lg.l: Noli certò promittere rem promiſſam tibi.

l.hi: Do not certainly promiſe a thing promiſed to thee.

lg.l: Fides eſt inde rara, quia multi loquuntur multa.

l.hi: Faith is therefore rare, becauſe many men ſpeak many things.

lg.l: Cùm quis laudet te, memento eſſe tuus judex.

l.hi: When one praiſeth thee, remember to be thine own judge.

lg.l: Noli credere plus aliis de te, quàm tu tibi.

l.hi: Do not believe others more concerning thee, than thou (believeſt) thy ſelf.

lg.l: Memento narrare multis officium alterius.

l.hi: Remember to tell to many the good turn of another.

lg.l: Atque ipſe ſileto, cùm tu benefeceris aliis.

l.hi: And do thou thy ſelf hold thy tongue, when thou ſhalt have done well to others.

lg.l: Dum ſenex recenſes facta & dicta multorum;

l.hi: Whilſt thou being old rehearſest the deeds and ſayings of many men;

lg.l: Fac quae ipſe juvenis feceris ſuccurrant tibi.
See that thoſe things which thy ſelf, being young, haſt done, may help thee.

l.hi: Ne cures, ſi quis loquatur tacito ſermone;

lg.l: Do not care, if one ſpeak with a whiſpering ſpeech.

l.hi: Ipſe conſcius ſibi putat omnia dici de ſe.

lg.l: He that is guilty to himſelf, thinks all things to be ſpoken of himſelf.

l.hi: Cum fueris foelix, caveto quae ſunt adverſa.

lg.l: When thou ſhalt be proſperous, take heed of the things that are adverſe.

l.hi: Ultima non reſpondent primis eodem curſu.

lg.l: The last things do not anſwer the firſt in the ſame courſe.

l.hi: Cum dubia & fragilis vita ſit tributa nobis;

lg.l: Seeing a doubtful and brittle life is afforded us;

l.hi: Noli ponere ſpem tibi in morte alterius.

lg.l: Do not place hope for thy ſelf in the death of another.

l.hi: Cum pauper amicus det tibi exiguum munus;

lg.l: When a poor friend giveth thee a ſmall preſent;

l.hi: Accipito placidè, & memento laudare plenè.

lg.l: Accept it chearfully, and remember to praiſe it fully.

l.hi: Cum natura creârit te nudum infantem;

lg.l: Seeing nature hath made thee a naked infant;

l.hi: Memento ferre patienter onus paupertatis.

lg.l: Remember to bear patiently the burthen of poverty.

l.hi: Ne timeas illam, quae eſt ultima finis vitae;

lg.l: Do not fear that which is the laſt end of life.

l.hi: Qui metuit mortem, perdit id ipſum quod vivit.

lg.l: He that feareth death, loſeth that very thing that he liveth, i. e. the pleaſure of living.

l.hi: Si nemo amicus reſpondet tibi pro meritis

lg.l: If no friend anſwer thee according to thy deſerts

l.hi: Noli incuſare Deum, ſed ipſe coerce te.

lg.l: Do not blame God, but do thou reſtrain thy ſelf.

l.hi: Utere parcè quaeſitis, ne quid deſit tibi.

lg.l: Ʋſe ſparingly things gotten, leſt any thing be wanting to thee.

l.hi: Et ut ſerves quod eſt, ſemper putato deeſſe tibi.

lg.l: And that thou may'ſt keep that which thou haſt, always think it is wanting to thee, (i. e. that thou wanteſt.)

l.hi: Nè promiſeris ulli bis, quod praeſtare potes;

lg.l: Do not promiſe any man twice, that which thou art able to perform.

l.hi: Nê ſis ventoſus, dum vis haberi urbanus.

lg.l: Leaſt thou beeſt a boaſter, whilſt thou wouldſt be accounted courteous.

l.hi: Qui ſimulat verbis, nec eſt fidus amicus corde.

lg.l: He that diſſembleth in words, and is not a faithful friend in heart.

l.hi: Tu quoque ſuc ſimile; ſic ars deluditur arte.

lg.l: Thou alſo do the like: thus craft is couzened with craft.

l.hi: Noli probare homines nimiúm blandos ſermone.

lg.l: Do not thou allow of men that are too cunning in their ſpeech.

l.hi: Fiſtula canit dulce, dum auceps decipit volucrem.

lg.l: The pipe ſings ſweetly, while the fowler deceiveth the bird.

l.hi: Si nati ſint tibi, nec opes, tunc inſtrue illos

lg.l:
If
ſons be to thee
thou haſt ſons
and not wealth, then inſtruct them

l.hi: Artibus quo poſſint defendere inopem vitam.

lg.l: In trades, that they may maintain a poor life.

l.hi: Putato carum quod vile eſt, vile, quod carum.

lg.l: Eſteem that to be dear which is cheap, and cheap which is dear.

l.hi: Sic nec habeberis parcus tibi, nec avarus ulli.

lg.l: So ſhalt thou be accounted neither ſparing to thy ſelf, nor covetous to any man.

l.hi: Tu ipſe nè feceris ea, quae ſoles culpare.

lg.l: Do not thou thy ſelf do thoſe things which thou uſeſt to blame.

l.hi: Turpe eſt doctori, cùm culpa redarguit ipſum.

lg.l: It is a foul thing for the teacher, when the fault confutes himſelf.

l.hi: Petito quod eſt juſtum, vel quod videatur honeſtum.

lg.l: Deſire what is juſt, or what may ſeem honeſt.

l.hi: Nam eſt ſtultum petere quod poſſit negari jure.

lg.l: For it is a fond thing to deſire what may be denyed by right.

l.hi: Nolito praeponere ignotum tibi notis;

lg.l: Do thou not prefer a thing unknown to thee, before things known.

l.hi: Cognita conſtant judicio, incognita caſu.

lg.l: Things known are grounded on judgment, unknown on chance.

l.hi: Cúm dubia vita verſetur incertis periclis.

lg.l: Seeing our life is converſant amongſt uncertain dangers.

l.hi: Quicunque laboras, pone diem pro lucro tibi.

lg.l: Whoſoever art troubled, account a day for gain to thee.

l.hi: Cùm poſſis vincere, cede interdum ſodali.

lg.l: When thou mayeſt overcome, give way ſometimes to thy companion:

l.hi: Quoniam dulces amici vincuntur obſequio.

lg.l: Becauſe ſweet friends are overcome by compliance.

l.hi: Ne dubites impendere parva, cùm petas magna.

lg.l: Doubt not to beſtow ſmall things, ſince thou may'ſt deſire great.

l.hi: Etenim gratia conjungit charos his rebus.

lg.l: For favour joyneth together dear friends by theſe things.

l.hi: Cave inferre litem cum quo gratia juncta eſt tibi.

lg.l:
Take heed you make no brabble
With whom good will is joyned to thee.
With him that is friends with thee?

l.hi: Ira generat odium, concordia nutrit amorem.

lg.l: Anger breeds hatred, concord nouriſheth love.

l.hi: Cùm dolor urget te in iram ob culpam ſervorum.

lg.l: When grief forceth thee to anger for the fault of thy ſervants.

l.hi: Ipſe moderare tibi ut poſſis parcere tuis.

lg.l: Do thou moderate thy ſelf that thou mayſt ſpare thy own.

l.hi: Interdum vince ferendo quem potes ſuperare.

lg.l: Sometimes overcome by ſuffering him whom thou canſt conquer.

l.hi: Enim patientia ſemper maxima virtus morum.

lg.l:
For patience (is) always the chiefeſt vertue of
manners.
moral vertues.

l.hi: Potiùs conſerva quae ſunt jam parta labore.

lg.l: Rather ſave thoſe things which are already got with pain;

l.hi: Cùm labor in damno eſt, mortalis egeſtas creſcit.

lg.l: When our labour is in (recovering) loſs, deadly poverty increaſeth.

l.hi: Cum foelix fueris interdum dapſilis notis,

lg.l: When thou in proſperity ſhalt be ſometimes frank to thy acquaintance,

l.hi: Et charis amicis, eſto ſemper proximus tibi.

lg.l: And dear friends, be thou always neareſt to thy ſelf.

l.hi: SI fortè velis cognoſcere cultum telluris,

lg.l: If perhaps thou wouldſt know the tillage of Land,
Legito Virgilium; quòd ſi magis laboras noſſe
Read Virgil, but if thou rather deſireſt to know
Vires herbarum, Macer dicet tibi carmine.
The vertues of herbs, Macer will tell thee in verſe.

l.hi: Si cupis noſcere Romana, vel Punica bella,

lg.l: If thou deſireſt to know the Roman or Carthaginian Wars,
Quaeras Lucanum, qui dicet praelia Martis.
Get Lucan, who will tell thee the Battels of (War.)

l.hi: Si libet quid amare, vel dicere amare legendo,

lg.l: If thou haſt any mind to love, or to learn to love by reading,
Petito Naſonem, ſin autem haec eſt cura tibi,
Get Ovid, but if this be thy care,

l.hi: Ut vivas ſapiens, audi, quo poſſis diſcere,

lg.l: That thou maiſt live wiſely, hear, to the end thou maist learn,

l.hi: Per quae aevum ſemotum vitiis traducitur.

lg.l: By what things an age free from vices is ſpent,

l.hi: Ergò ades, & diſce legendo quae ſapientia ſit.

lg.l: Therefore come, and learn by reading what wiſdom is.

l.hi: MEmento prodeſſe etiam ignotis ſi potes.

lg.l: Remember to pleaſure even thoſe thou knowest not, if thou canst.

l.hi: Utilius regno, acquirere amicos meritis.

lg.l: It is better than a Kingdom to get friends by deſert.

l.hi: Mitte inquirere arcana Dei, & quid coelum ſit.

lg.l: Forbear to inquire after the ſecrets of God, and what heaven is.
Cùm ſis mortalis, cura quae ſunt mortalia;

l.hi: Seeing thou art mortal, mind thoſe things that are mortal.

lg.l: Linque metum lethi, nam ſtultum eſt in omni tempore;

l.hi: Leave the fear of death, for it is a fooliſh thing at all times;

lg.l: Dum metuis mortem, amittis gaudia vitae.

l.hi: Whilſt thou feareſt death, thou loſeſt the pleaſures of life.

lg.l: Noli iratus contendere de incerta re,

l.hi: Do thou not, being angry, contend about an uncertain thing.

lg.l: Ira impedit animum, nè poſſit cernere verum.

l.hi: Anger hindreth the mind that it cannot diſcern the truth.

lg.l: Fac ſumptum propere, cùm res ipſa deſiderat;

l.hi: Beſtow coſt readily, when the thing it ſelf requireth.

lg.l: Etenim aliquid eſt dandum, cùm tempus aut res poſtulat,

l.hi: For ſomething is to be given, when time or occaſion requires.

lg.l: Fugito quod eſt nimium, memento gaudere parvo;

l.hi: Avoid what is too much, remember to delight in a little;

lg.l: Puppis eſt magis tuta, quae fertur modico flumine.

l.hi: The ſhip is more ſafe which is carried in a little River.

lg.l: Memento prudens celare ſocios quod pudeat;

l.hi: Remember wiſely to conceal from thy fellows that whereof thou maiſt be aſhamed;

lg.l: Ne plures culpent id quod diſplicet tibi uni.

l.hi: Leſt many blame that which diſliketh thee alone.

lg.l: Nolo putes pravos homines lucrari peccata,

l.hi: I will not that thou ſhouldſt think that wicked men do gain by their ſins.

lg.l: Peccata latent temporibus, & patent tempore.

l.hi: Sins lye hid for a time, and they appear in time.

lg.l: Noli contemnere vires exigui corporis.

l.hi: Do not contemn the ſtrength of a little body.

lg.l: Pollet conſilio, cui natura negavit vim.

l.hi: He excells in wiſdom, to whom nature hath denyed ſtrength.

lg.l: Cede tempore, quem ſcieris non eſſe parem tibi:

l.hi: Yield in time to him whom thou know'ſt is not equal for thee.

lg.l: Saepe videmus victorem ſuperari à victo.

l.hi: We often ſee the conqueror to be overcome by the conquered party.

lg.l: Noli contendere verbis adverſus notum.

l.hi: Do not contend in words againſt an acquaintance.

lg.l: Maxima lis interdum creſcit minimis verbis.

l.hi: The greateſt controverſie ſometimes groweth from the leaſt words.

lg.l: Noli perquirere ſorre quid Deus intendat.

l.hi: Do not inquire by lot what God intendeth.

lg.l: Ipſe deliberat, ſine te, quid ſtatuat de te.

l.hi: He deliberateth, without thee, what he reſolves concerning thee.

lg.l: Memento vitare invidiam nimio cultu:

l.hi: Remember to avoid envy for too much gaudineſs.

lg.l: Quae ſi non laedat, tamen moleſtum ſufferre eſt hanc.

l.hi: Which though it hurt thee not, yet it is a troubleſome thing to bear this.

lg.l: Eſto forti animo cùm ſis iniquè damnatus.

l.hi: Be of good courage when thou art unjuſtly condemned.

lg.l: Nemo gaudet diu, qui vincit iniquo judice.

l.hi: No man joyeth long who getteth the better by a corrupt Judge.

lg.l: Noli referre maledicta litis praeteritae,

l.hi: Do not rehearſe the railing words of a contention paſt.

lg.l: Eſt malorum, meminiſſe iram poſt inimicitias.

l.hi: It is the property of wicked men to remember anger after falling out.

lg.l: Nec ipſe collaudes te, nec culpaveris te.

l.hi: Neither do thou thy ſelf praiſe thy ſelf, nor blame thy ſelf.

lg.l: Stulti faciunt hoc, quos inanis gloria vexat.

l.hi: Fools do this, whom vain glory vexeth.

lg.l: Utere modicè quaeſitis, dum ſumptus abundat.

l.hi: Uſe ſparingly goods gotten, whilſt gettings abound.

lg.l: Quod partum eſt longo tempore, labitur exiguo.

l.hi: That which is got in a long time, conſumeth in a little time.

lg.l: Eſto inſipiens, cùm tempus aut res poſtulat.

l.hi: Be (like) a fool when time or occaſion requireth.

lg.l: Eſt ſumma prudentia ſimulare ſtultitiam loco.

l.hi: It is the greateſt diſcretion to counterfeit folly upon occaſion.

lg.l: Fugito luxuriam, ſimul & memento vitare

l.hi: Avoid prodigality, and alſo to remember to avoid

lg.l: Crimen avaritiae, nam ſunt contraria famae.

l.hi: The crime of covetouſneſs, for they are contrary to good report.

lg.l: Nolito credere ſemper referenti quaedam.

l.hi: Do not believe one that always telleth ſome (news.)

lg.l: Exigua fides eſt tribuenda iis qui loquuntur multa.

l.hi: Small credit is to be given to them that ſpeak many words.

lg.l: Tu noli ignoſcere tibi quod peccas potu:

l.hi: Do not thou pardon thy ſelf, that thou offendest in drink:

lg.l: Nam eſt nullum crimen vini, ſed culpa bibentis.

l.hi: For it is no fault of the Wine, but the fault of the drinker.

lg.l: Committe arcanum conſilium tacito ſodali.

l.hi: Commit thy ſecret counſel to thy cloſe companion.

lg.l: Committe auxilium corporis fideli medico.

l.hi: Commit the cure of thy body to a faithful Phyſician.

lg.l: Noli tu ferre moleſtè indignos ſucceſſus:

l.hi: Do not thou take ill unworthy ſucceſſes:

lg.l: Fortuna indulget malis, ut poſſit laedere.

l.hi: Fortune pampereth evil men that ſhe may hurt them.

lg.l: Proſpice, hos caſus eſſe ferendos, qui veniunt:

l.hi: Foreſee, that theſe chances are to be endured, which fall out.

lg.l: Nam quicquid praevideris antè, laedit leviùs.

l.hi: For whatſoever thou ſhalt foreſee before, hurteth leſs.

lg.l: Noli ſubmietere animum in adverſis rebus:

l.hi: Do not let down thy co • rage in adverſity:

lg.l: Retine ſpem; ſpes una nec relinquit hominem morte.

l.hi: Retain hope; hope only doth not leave a man in death.

lg.l: Noli demittere rem quam noſcis aptam tibi.

l.hi: Do not let ſlip a thing which thou knowest fit for thee:

lg.l: Occaſio eſt calva poſt, fr • ntè capillatâ.

l.hi: Opportunity is bald behind, with a buſhy Forehead.

lg.l: Specta quod ſequitur, atque videto quod imminet antè.

l.hi: Look at that which followeth, and ſee that which is ready to come before.

lg.l: Imitare illum Deum qui ſpectat utramque partem.

l.hi: Imitate that God which looketh

lg.l: Ut valeas fortior, eſto interdum parcior:

l.hi: That thou maiſt be ſtrong be ſometimes more ſparing.

lg.l: Pauca debentur voluptati, plura ſaluti.

l.hi: Few things are due to pleaſure (but) more to health.

lg.l: Unus nunquam contempſeris judicium populi.

l.hi: Being (but) one, never ſlight the judgment of the people:

lg.l: Ne placeas nulli, dum vis contemnere multos.

l.hi: Leſt thou pleaſe none, whilſt thou wilt ſcorn many.

lg.l: Sit tibi cura ſalutis praecipuè quod primum eſt.

l.hi: Have thou a care of thy health eſpecially, which is the main thing.

lg.l: Cùm ſis cauſa doloris tibi, ne culpes tempora.

l.hi: When thou art a cauſe of ſorrow to thy ſelf, blame not the times.

lg.l: Nè cures ſomnia, nam mens humana ſperans,

l.hi: Do not heed dreams, for mans mind hoping,

lg.l: Cernit id ipſum per ſomnum quod optat cùm vigilat.

l.hi: Seeth that very thing in ſleep which it deſireth when it is awake.

lg.l: LEctor quicunque velis cognoſcere hoc carmen,

l.hi: Reader, whoſoever wouldst know this Poem,

lg.l: Feres haec praecepta, quae ſunt gratiſſima vitae.

l.hi: Thou muſt bear (away) theſe precepts which are very profitable for (ones) life.

lg.l: Inſtrue animum praeceptis, nec ceſſes diſcere.

l.hi: Furniſh thy mind with precepts, and ceaſe not to learn.

lg.l: Nam vita eſt quaſi imago mortis ſine doctrinâ.

l.hi: For life is as it were the image of death without learning.

lg.l: Feres multa commoda; ſin autem ſpreveris illud,

l.hi: Thou ſhalt bear away much benefit; but if thou neglect it,

lg.l: Ipſe non neglexeris meſcriptorem, ſed te.

l.hi: Thou ſhalt not neglect me the writer, but thy ſelf.

lg.l: NE cures verba malorum, cum vivas rectè.

l.hi: Regard not the words of ill men, when thou liveſt well.

lg.l: Non eſt noſtri arbitrii quid quiſque loquatur.

l.hi: It is not in our power what any one may ſay.

lg.l: Productus teſtis, celato crimen amici.

l.hi: Being produced as a witneſs, conceal the fault of thy friend.

lg.l: Quantumcunque potes, tamen pudore ſalvo antê.

As much us thou canſt, yet
thy honour being ſafe before.
ſaving thy credit firſt.
Memento cavere blandos, & blaeſos ſermones:
Remember to take heed of fawning and liſping ſpeeches.
Simplicitas veri eſt ſana, fraus loquendi eſt ficta.

The ſimplieity of truth is ſound,
deceit of ſpeech is feigned.
deceitful ſpeech is feigned.
Fugito ſegnitiem, quae fertur ignavia vitae;
Eſchew ſloathfulneſs, which is called lazineſs of life.
Nam cum animus languet, inertia conſumit corpus.
For when the mind is lazie, lazineſs conſumeth the body.
Interdum interpone gaudia tuis curis.
Sometimes interpoſe joys with thy cares.
Ut poſſis ſufferre quemvis laborem animo.
That thou mayſt endure any labour in thy mind.
Ne unquam carpſeris dictum aut factum alterius.
Do not at any time carp at the ſaying or doing of another.
Ne alter derideat te ſimili exemplo.
Leſt another jeer thee by the like example.
Serva augendo quae ſuprema ſors dederit tibi.
Save in increaſing thoſe things which the laſt will hath granted thee.
Notata fabulis; ne ſis quem fama loquatur.

Being ſet down in the Will,
leſt thou beeſt he whom reports may talk of.
leſt thou beeſt he whom folk may talk on.
Cum divitiae ſuperant tibi in fine ſenectae.
When riches abound to thee in the end of thy old age.
Facito vivas munificus, non parcus amicis.
See thou live munificent, not ſparing to thy friends.
Dominus nè deſpice utile conſilium ſervi.
Thou being a maſter, do not deſpiſe the good counſel of thy ſervant,
Tempſeris unquam ſenſum nullius ſi prodeſt.
Deſpiſe not at any time the opinion of any man, if it be good.
Si non eſt rebus & in cenſu quod fuit ante.
If there be not in thy means an eſtate what there was before.
Fac vivas contentus eo quod tempora praebent.
See thou live content with that which the times afford.
Fuge nè ducas uxorem ſub nomine dotis:
Beware that thou marry not a wife for her portions ſake.
Nec velis retinere, ſi coeperit eſſe moleſta.
And deſire not to keep her, if ſhe begin to be troubleſome.
Diſce exemplo multorum, quae facta ſequaris,
Learn by the examples of many what deeds thou maiſt follow.
Quae fugias; vita aliena eſt magiſtra nobis.
And what thou maiſt ſhun; another mans life is a Miſtreſs to us.
Tentes id quod potes, nè preſſus pondere operis,
Attempt that which thou art able to do, leſt being preſſed with the weight of the work,
Labor ſuccumbat, & relinquas tentata fruſtra.
Thy labour fail, and thou leave the thing attempted in vain.
Nolito tacere quod noſti haud rectè factum,
Do not thou conceal what thou knoweſt is not well done,
Ne videare tacendo velle imitari malos.
Leſt thou ſeem by concealing to be willing to imitate bad men.
Rogato auxilium judicis ſub iniqua lege;
Intreat the aid of the judge under a harſh law;
Etiam leges ipſae cupiunt ut regantur jure.
Even the laws themſelves deſire that they may be ruled by right.
Memento ferre patienter quod pateris meritò;
Remember to bear patiently what thou ſuffereſt deſervedly;
Quae cùm ſi reus tibi, damna ipſum, te judice.
And when thou art guilty (to thy ſelf) condemn (thy) ſelf, thou (thy ſelf) being the Judge.
Facito legas multa, perlectis, perlege multa;
See thou read many things, when thoſe are readover, readover many things;
Nam poetae canunt miranda, ſed non credenda.
For Poets ſing ſtrange things, but not to be believed.
Fac ſis modeſtus ſermone inter convivas;
See thou beeſt modeſt in thy talk amongſt ſtrangers;
Ne dicare loquax dum vis haberi urbanus.
Lest thou be called talkative, whilſt thou art willing to be accounted mannerly.
Nolito timere verbairatae conjugis,
Do not fear the words of thy angry wife,
Nam foemina ſtruit inſidias lachrymis, dum plorat.
For a woman layeth ſnares with her tears, whilst ſhe weepeth.
Utere quaeſitis, ſed ne videaris abuti.
Ʋſe (goods) gotten, but not to abuſe them.
Qui conſumunt ſua, ſequuntur aliena cum deeſt.
They that waſt their own goods, follow other mens, when they want.
Fac proponas tibi, mortem non eſſe timendam.
See thou propound to thy ſelf, that death is not to be feared.
Quae ſi non eſt bona, tamen illa eſt finis malorum.
Which if it be not good, yet it is the end of evils.
Memento ferre linguam uxoris, ſi frugi eſt.
Remember to endure thy wives tongue, if ſhe be a good huswife.
Namque eſt malum velle pati nil, nee poſſe tacere.
For it is a bad thing to be willing to ſuffer nothing, and not to be able to keep ſilence.
Dilige charos parences non aegrâ pietate.
Love thy dear parents with an unconſtrained love.
Nec offendas matrem, dum vis eſſe bonus parenti.
And offend not thy mother, whilst thou art willing to be dutiful to thy Father.
Quicunque cupis traducere ſecuram vitam,
Whoſoever deſireth to lead a quiet life,
Nec animum haerere vitiis quae obſunt moribus.
And not (to have) thy mind ſtick in vices which hurt manners.
Memento haec praecepta ſemper relegenda tibi.
Remember theſe precepts (are) always to be read by thee.
Invenies aliquid, in quo utare te magiſtro.
Thou ſhalt find ſomething, in which thou maiſt uſe thy ſelf (as maſter)
i. e. thou maiſt be thine own teacher, or, learn to order thy ſelf.
DEſpice divitias, ſi vis eſſe beatus animo;
Scorn riches, if thou wilt be happy in mind;
Quas qui ſuſpiciunt, ſemper avari mendicant,
Which they that gaze upon, being always covetous, live beggerly.
Commoda naturae deerunt tibi nullo tempore,
The benefits of nature will be wanting to thee at no time,
Si fueris contentus eo quod uſus poſtulat.
If thou ſhalt be content with that which need requireth.
Cùm ſis incautus, nec gubernes rem ratione,
When thou art unwary, and doſt not govern thy eſtate with diſcretion,
Noli dicere fortunam caecam, quae non eſt.
Do not call fortune blind, which is not.
Dilige denarium, ſed dilige formam parcè,
Love the penny, but love (its) ſtamp ſparingly,
Quam nemo ſanctus, nec honeſtus, captat habere.
Which no holy, nor honest man, coveteth to have.
Cùm fueris locuples, memento curare corpus.
When thou ſhalt be rich, remember to look to thy body.
Aeger dives habet nummos, ſed non habet ipſum.
A ſick rich man hath money, but he hath not himſelf.
Cùm diſcens aliquando tuleris verbera magiſtri.
Seeing when thou learneſt, thou ſometimes endurest the jerks of thy master.
Fer imperium patris, cùm exit in iram verbis.
Endure the command of (thy) Father, when he groweth angry in words.
Age res quae proſunt, rurſus memento vitare,
Do things that profit, again remember to ſhun things
In quibus ineſt error, nec eſt certa ſpes laboris.
In which there is a mistake, and there is no certain hope (of requital) of lost labour.

l.hi: Concede gratis roganti quod potes donare,

lg.l: Grant freely to him that asketh thee, that which thou canst give.

l.hi: Nam eſt in parté lucrorum, feciſſe rectè bonis.

lg.l: For it is in part of gains, to have done well to good men.

l.hi: Diſcute confeſtim quid ſit, ſuſpectum eſt tibi,

lg.l: Examine it preſently what it is, which is ſuſpected to thee,

l.hi: Namque ſolent nocere quae ſunt neglecta primo

lg.l: For thoſe things uſe to hurt, which are neglected at first.

l.hi: Cùm damnoſa voluptas Veneris detineat te,

lg.l: When the hurtful pleaſure of leachery detaineth thee,

l.hi: Noli indulgere gulae quae eſt amica ventris:

lg.l: Do not pamper gluttony, which is a friend of the bellies.

l.hi: Cùm proponas tibi timere cuncta animalia,

lg.l: When thou reſolvest with thy ſelf to fear all living creatures,

l.hi: Praecipio tibi unum hominem eſſe timendum plus.

lg.l: I warn thee that only man is to be feared more.

l.hi: Cùm praevalidae vires fuerint tibi in corpore,

lg.l: When thou ſhalt have able ſtrength in body

l.hi: Fac ſapias, ſic tu poteris haberi vir fortis.

lg.l: See thou beeſt wiſe, ſo thou maiſt be accounted a gallant man.

l.hi: Petito auxilium à notis, ſi forte laboras,

lg.l: Deſire help of thy acquaintance, if perhaps thou art in trouble.

l.hi: Nec quiſquam melior medicus, quàm fidus amicus.

lg.l: There is not any better Phyſician than a faithful friend.

l.hi: Cur victima moritur pro te, cùm ipſe ſis nocens?

lg.l: Why doth a beaſt ſacrificed die for thee, when thou thy ſelf art faulty?

l.hi: Eſt ſtultitia, ſperare ſalutem morte alterius.

lg.l: It is folly to hope for ſalvation by the death of another.

l.hi: Cum quaeris tibi vel ſocium, vel fidum amicum,

lg.l: When thou ſeekest for thy ſelf either a companion, or a faithful friend,

l.hi: Non fortuna, ſed vita hominis eſt quaerenda tibi.

lg.l: Not the fortune, but the life of the man is to be enquired after by thee.

l.hi: Utere opibus quaeſitis, fuge nomen avari,

lg.l: Make uſe of thy wealth gotten, avoid the name of a covetous man.

l.hi: Quid divitiae proſunt tibi, ſi abundas pauper?

lg.l: What do riches profit thee if thou haſt abundance and art poor.

l.hi: Si cupis ſervare honeſtam famam, dum vivis,

lg.l: If thou deſireſt to keep an honest name, whilſt thou livest,

l.hi: Fac fugias animo quae ſunt mala gaudia vitae.

lg.l: See that thou ſhun with thy mind thoſe things that are the wicked pleaſures of life.

l.hi: Cum ſapias animo noli irridere ſenectam.

lg.l: When thou art wiſe in mind do not thou mock old age.

l.hi: Nam quicunque ſenex, puerilis ſenſus eſt in illo:

lg.l: For whoſoever is old, a childiſh underſtanding is in him:

l.hi: Diſce aliquid, nam cùm fortuna recedit ſubitò,

lg.l: Learn ſomething; for when fortune goes back on a ſudden,

l.hi: Ars remanet, quae non unquam deſerit vitam hominis.

lg.l: Skill remaineth, which never forſaketh the life of man.

l.hi: Tacitus perſpicito omnia quae quiſque loquatur,

lg.l: Keep ſilence, conſider all things which any one ſaith,

l.hi: Sermo celat mores hominum, idem indicat.

lg.l: Speech conceals the manners of men, and the ſame diſcovers them.

l.hi: Exerce ſtudium quamvis perceperis artem,

lg.l: Uſe ſtudy, though thou underſtand the art.

l.hi: Ut cura adjuvat ingenium, ſic & manus uſum.

lg.l: As care helpeth the wit, ſo alſo the hand helpeth uſe.

l.hi: Ne multum cures tempora lethi futuri,

lg.l: Do not much care for the time of death to come.

l.hi: Is non timet mortem, qui ſcit contemnere vitam.

lg.l: He doth not fear death, who knoweth to contemn life.

l.hi: Diſce ſed à doctis, ipſe doceto indoctos.

lg.l: Learn but of them that are learned, do thou thy ſelf teach the unlearned.

l.hi: Etenim doctrina bonarum rerum eſt propaganda.

lg.l: For the doctrine of good things is to be propagated.

l.hi: Bibe hoc quod proſit, ſi tu vis vivere ſanus.

lg.l: Drink that which may do thee good, if thou wilt live in health.

l.hi: Voluptas eſt quandoque cauſa mali morbi homini.

lg.l: Pleaſure is ſometimes a cauſe of an ill diſeaſe to a man.

l.hi: Quodcunque laudaris palàm quodcunque probaris,

lg.l: Whatſoever thou ſhalt have praiſed openly (or) whatſoever thou ſhalt have allowed.

l.hi: Vide ne damnes hoc rurſus crimine levitatis.

lg.l: See thou doſt not condemn this again through the fault of lightneſs.

l.hi: Tranquillis rebus caveto quae ſunt adverſa.

lg.l: In proſperity beware of things that are adverſe.

l.hi: Rurſus memento ſperare melius in adverſis.

lg.l: Again remember to hope better in adverſity.

l.hi: Ne ceſſes diſcere, ſapientia creſcit curâ.

lg.l: Ceaſe not to learn, wiſdom increaſeth by care,

l.hi: Rara prudentia datur longo uſu temporis.

lg.l: Rare wiſdom is given by long uſe of time.

l.hi: Laudato parcè; nam una dies monſtrabit,

lg.l: Praiſe ſparingly; for one day will ſhew,

l.hi: Qualis amicus fuerit, quem tu ſaepe probaris.

lg.l: What a friend he hath been, whom thou hast often commended.

l.hi: Ne pudeat, velle te doceri quae neſcieris;

lg.l: Be not aſhamed, to be willing that thou beeſt taught what things thou knowest not;

l.hi: Eſt laus ſcire aliquid; eſt pudor velle diſcere nil.

lg.l: It is a commendation to know ſomething; it is a ſhame to be willing to learn nothing.

l.hi: Cùm lis & voluptas eſt juncta Venere & Baccho;

lg.l: Seeing contention and pleaſure is joyned with Venery and Wine.

l.hi: Complectere animo quod lautum eſt, ſed fuge lites.

lg.l: Embrace in thy mind that which is pleaſant, but avoid the contentions.

l.hi: Memento vitare demiſſos animo, actacitos,

lg.l: Remember to avoid men of a ſullen diſpoſition, and ſilent,

l.hi: Unda forſan latet altiùs, quà flumen eſt placidum.

lg.l: The water perhaps is deeper where the River is calm.

l.hi: Cùm fortuna tuarum rerum diſpliceat tibi.

lg.l: When the fortune of thy means diſliketh thee,

l.hi: Specta alterius quo diſcrimine ſis pejor.

lg.l: Look at another mans (and) in what difference thou art worſe.

l.hi: Tenta id quod potes, nam eſt multò tutius.

lg.l: Attempt that which thou canſt do for it is much ſafer,

l.hi: Carpere littus remis, quàm tèndere velum in altum.

lg.l: To keep near the ſhoar with Oars, than to hoiſt up the ſail into the deep.

l.hi: Noli pravè contendere contra juſtum hominem;

lg.l: Do not maliciouſly contend againſt a juſt man;

l.hi: Enim Deus ſemper ulciſcitur injuſtas iras.

lg.l: For God doth always revenge unjuſt contentions.

l.hi: Opibus ereptis, noli gaudere querendo;

lg.l: When thy wealth is taken away, do not delight in complaining.

l.hi: Sed potiùs gaude, ſi contingit tibi habere.

lg.l: But rather rejoyce, if it befall thee to have wealth.

l.hi: Eſt gravis jactùra amittere quae ſunt, damnis.

lg.l: It is a grievous loſs to loſe what we have by miſhaps:

l.hi: Sunt quaedam quae decet amicum ferre patienter.

lg.l: There be ſome (miſhaps) which it becometh a friend to bear patiently.

l.hi: Noli promittere tibi longa tempora vitae:

lg.l: Do not promiſe to thy ſelf long time of life:

l.hi: Quocunque ingrederis, mors umbra corporis ſequitur.

lg.l: Which way ſoever thou goest, death the ſhadow of the body followeth.

l.hi: Placa Deum thure, ſine vitulum creſcat aratro:

lg.l: Pacifie God with frankincenſe, ſuffer the calf to grow for the plough,

l.hi: Ne credas placare Deum, dum litatur caede.

lg.l: Do not think to appeaſe God, whilſt thou ſacrificeſt with ſlaughter.

l.hi: Laeſus cede locum fortunae, cede potenti;

lg.l: Being hurt give place to fortune, give place to a great man;

l.hi: Qui potuit cedere, aliquando valebit prodeſſe.

lg.l: He that could give way will ſometimes be able to do good.

l.hi: Ipſe caſtiga te ſubinde, cum peccâris quid;

lg.l: Do thou chaſtiſe thy ſelf forthwith, when thou haſt offended in any thing.

l.hi: Dum ſan • s vulnera, dolor eſt medicina doloris.

lg.l: Whilſt thou healeſt wounds, ſmart is the remedy of ſmart.
Nunquam damnaris amicum poſt longum tempus:

l.hi: Never condemn thy friend after a long time:

lg.l: Mutavit mores, ſed memento prima pignora.

l.hi: He hath changed his manners, but remember the firſt pledges.

lg.l: Quò ſis magis gratior officiis eſto charior,

l.hi: That thou maiſt be the more pleaſing in thy ſervice, be the more indeared,

lg.l: Ne ſubeas nomen, quod dicitur Officii perda.

l.hi: Leſt thou undergo the name which is called a thankleſs perſon.

lg.l: Suſpectus caveas, ne ſis miſer omnibus horis,

l.hi: Being ſuſpected, take heed thou beeſt not miſerable every hour.

lg.l: Nam mors eſt aptiſſima timidis & ſuſpectis.

l.hi: For death is moſt fit for fearful and ſuſpected perſons.

lg.l: Cùm mercatus fueris ſervos in proprios uſus,

l.hi: When thou ſhalt have bought ſlaves for thy own uſe,

lg.l: Et dicas famulos, tamen memento eſſe homines.

l.hi: And call'ſt them ſervants, yet remèmber they are men.

lg.l: Prima occaſio eſt capiend a tibi quam primùm:

l.hi: The firſt occaſion is to be taken by thee as ſoon as can be:

lg.l: Ne quaeras rurſus quae neglexeris jam antè.

l.hi: Leſt thou ſeek again what thou haſt neglected afore.

lg.l: Noli gaudere repentinâ morte malorum:

l.hi: Do not rejoyce at the ſudden death of evil men.

lg.l: Obeunt felices, quorum vita eſt ſine crimine.

l.hi: They dye happy whoſe life is without fault.

lg.l: Cúm fit tibi conjux, nec res, & fama laboret,

l.hi: When thou haſt a wife, and no means, and her name is ſuſpected,

lg.l: Ducas inimicum nomen amici vitandum.

l.hi: Think that the hurtful name of a friend is to be avoided.

lg.l: Cùm contingat tibi cognoſcere multa ſtudio,

l.hi: When it befalls thee to know many things by ſtudy,

lg.l: Fac diſcas multa, & vites neſcire doceri.

l.hi: See thou learn many things, and ſhun not to know to be taught.

lg.l: Miraris me ſcribere verſus nudis verbis?

l.hi: Dost thou wonder that I write Verſes in bare words?

lg.l: Brevitas ſenſus fecit conjungere hos binos;

l.hi: The ſhortneſs of the ſentence made me joyn theſe Verſes two and two together.

div.head: Index rerum in Catonis Diſtichis. Prior numerus librum, poſterior autem Diſtichon tibi notat.
